document.text: Virginian Railway Plans. Norfolk.An ambitious plan for the development of the Virginian Railway is foreshadowed by the action of the stockholders at their meeting here in authorizing the issuance of a coupon bond mortgage not to exceed 75,000,- 000. Of the proceeds of the issue about two-thirds, it is said, will be used for improvements and extensions. The Virginian Railway was built by the late H. H. Rogers and is still con trolled by his estate. It? eastern terminus is at Norfolk and its westd n terminus at Deepwater, W. Va where it connects with the Chesapeake and Ohio. It is believed to be the present plan of the company to extend the line to Cincinnati in order to obtain a. Western outlet.

document.text: The Virginian Railway Company will reduce its capital stock by 3,- 678,500. This will occur at the an nual meeting of the company to be held at Norfolk, February 1. It has been recommended by resolution of the board of directors, and will in all probability be adopted by the stock holders. The proposition is to reduce the capital stock of the company from 62,805,000 to 59,226,500 and divided Into shares of 100 each this to be ac complished by reducing the common stock now issued and outstanding from 34,850,000 to not less than 31,271,- 600 divided into shares of 100 each.

document.text: The jury rendered a verdict of 7,000 in favor of the plaintiff in the case of O. C. Bel I vs. Virginian Railway Com pany. The case had been on trial since May 19, and was the third time it was tried at Christiansburg, both former verdicts having been revoked by the Supreme Court of Appeals. Bell was a mail clerk on the Virginian and claims to have suffered a fracture of the small bones of the neck, as a re sult of the sliding door of the car striking him when a train he was on  came to a sudden stop at I ronton, on j October 26, 1911. He claimed the com- ! pany was liable because it had pro-  vided no hook to the door. The case  probably will go to the Supreme Court, j

The load went through her heart. Her mother, Mrs. Amos Moore, and her sister, Fannie, rushed from the house, 100 yards distant, and found the lifeless body lying on the floor, the blood gushing from an awful wound in the breast. Miss Moore leaves a brother and five sisters, including Miss Annie Moore, of Baltimore, and Mrs. Susie Schultz, of Cumberland, Md. Miss Moore had suffered from a nervous breakdown and was despondent. Charlottesville.At a faculty meet ing at the University of Virginia Dr. Wilton Wylie Humphreys, Prof. Ormond Stone and Isaac Kimber Moran tendered their resignations to President Alderman. They are all over 66 years of age and have served the university for 25 years or more. There fore, under the provisions of the Car negie fund for retired teachers yearly payments equal to a certain percentage o! their aalarles will be made to them. For seven years he was professor of astronomy in the University of Cincinnati and director of the Cincinnati Observatory. Mr. Moran has been husar of the uni versity for many years. document.text: Norman Hill Bates, retired rail road conductor for the Virginian Railway, died yesterday at 100 P. M. at Virginia Baptist Hospital. Born in Spout Spring, he was the son of Mrs. Edmonia Jones Bates and the late Rufus Hill Bates. A veteran of World War I, Mr. Bates was a member of the Order of Railroad Conductors, the Broth erhood of Railroad Trainman, the American Legion Post 102, and the Masonic Lodge 304. In addition to his mother, he is survived by one daughter, Miss Joanne Bates, Sebrell five sisters, Mrs. F. O. Jones, Mrs. C. R. Mor ton, Mrs. C. W. Adams, Mrs. E. T. Sours and Lucille Bates, all of Spout Spring three brothers, Ar thur D Bates and W. Rufus Rates, Spout Spring, and Edward L. Bates, Brookneal. Funeral services will be held at 3 P. M. Friday in Lynchburg, with burial in Spring Hill Cemetery.

document.text: On The H oad Dear T im es  Three weeks ago we left, our historic county of Appomattox for a visit to loved ones in Blue- field, W. Va. The weather has been perfeotdear skies, little rain, and no frost. Vegetation has not been killed and flowers are blooming prettily in the yard of every home. Bluefleld is a progressive oity, with its handsome homes, wide, olean streets and pretty churohes of various denominations. Wher ever one travels through the country one finds nicely graded roads, suitable for automobiles especially, of whioh one sees a large number, though one sees many horses, large and fat. While there we were fortu nate in seeing The Birth of a Nation, a moving pioture that oannot be desoribed even by one gifted in pen pictures. Holston Methodist confer ence was in session and many ministers availed themselves of the rare opportunity of attend ing this wonderful portrayal of that reconstruction period, so fresh in the memory of some and which will now be indelli- bly impressed upon the minds of those a ho have lived since that dreadful and eventful pe riod. After a oharming visit to Bluefleld we have oome to Tams, in Raleigh county, W. Va , a mining town containing a number of neat homes, all lighted by electricity. It con- taine two churobeB, a graded school, hotel and opera house. It is built on the Virginian Railway,and oars heavily load ed with- coal are constantly passing, some of the engines drawiog ninety oars, oarrying this valuable mineral to our eastern oities. Not long ago the state railway au thorities in Melbourne, Australia, had to Investigate a caae of a guards leav ing his van, walking alongtfle foot plates, clambering up the engine, and making a furious assault upon the driver, the train going at full speed all the while. They are now inquiring into another curious Incident. In this case somebody forgot to fix the coup lings between the engine and the train. When the signal was given the engine steamed out ot the atatlon by itself, leaving carriagas and passen gers in the lurch. Guard, atatlonmos- ter, porters and spectators yelled, but without effect. The engine ran tor sis miles before it was discovered that it had nothing behind it. The most dis quieting feature of the incident was that it passed several signal boxes without receiving any warning to stop.  __________ Garfields Nomination. At the Republican national conven tion In 1880 the Blaine Half-Breeds to use the nomenclature of the day and the Grant Stalwarts, 300 in number, hugged each other in death grapple. They crushed each other and Garfield scampered off with the nomination for. president. When leaving Wash ington ,to attend the convention as leader of the Sherman delegates, Gar field was asked by John Randolph Tucker of Virginia Whom are you going to dominate? Garfield is said to have loved Ran. Tucker. They were far. asunder in politics, but there were love and affection and intellectual kinship . between the Virginian and the Ohioan. Garfield put his arm around, Tuckers shoulders and whis pered. Keep your eyes on me. And so it was. Garfield became President and Blaine took the secretaryship of state, to keep his hand on the helm, his friends said. To watch the Peru vian guano beds, his enemies re plied.Washington Letter toRich mond Va. Times.

Ackley, State secretary of the organization, now in Little Rock, Ark. Mr. Lee is a Virginian and was once student secretary for Virginia. Pulaski.In the one-day campaign Pulaski citizens pledged- 40,000 to secure the preparatory school which Emory and Henry College of the Meth odist Church is to establish. Action is to be reported to the committee on location. If accepted the town has several sites in view. Lynchburg.The Southern Railway system has restored section men who were cut off some weeks ago to their Jobs. The section forces recently were given double sections to work with re duced forces. These have now been restored, but it is understood there has been a cut of 5 cents an hour in the pay of the section men. Winchester.Bobbie Forney, four- year-old son of Robert Forney, was run over and killed by a bakery truck driven by Julian Rogers. Witnesses said the accident appeared unavoid able. The boys father was the ser geant who planted the American col ors on the wall of Peking during the Boxer uprising in China. Norfolk.Heavy damage to early potatoes was done by tbe recent frost in Norfolk, Princess Anne and Nanse- mond counties, according to reports received from all parts of this section at the office of the Southern Produce Exchange. Other crops damaged by the extreme cold were strawberries, which were in full bloom and other early truck. Winchester.Representative Thos. W. Harrison, Democrat, Winchester, member of tbe House from the Seventh Virginia District, is reported to have the backing of the Virginia delegation In Congress for a place on the appropriations committee, and he also may be assigned a place on the rivers and harbors sub-committee. He has been a member of the committee on military affairs since succeeding James Hay, about five years ago. document.text: By FRANCES H. PAULETTE With so much thought and energy going into the Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival, a backward glance at the Depot seems in order. It was n the year of 1852 that the first railroad was built through the county of Appomattox. It was called the Atlantic, Mississippi and Ohio Railroad. The first passenger train went through Appomattox enroute tp Roanoke in November of 1852. At that time the engine was fired with wood the wood was cut, hauled, and stacked along side the tracks. Some time later the railroad was renamed The Virginian and Tennessee Railroad. Today it is the Norfolk and Western Railway System. Looking out over the fields of the Valley and the Pied mont country across the mountains at this season of the year it la hard to conceive that any- Virginia farmer houses so small a crop as thatand yet If the average of the state .shall be brought up to six barrels, on the basis of,last years acreage and the ten-year average farm price, approxi mately 96,900,000 a year would be add ed tt the Income of Virginia farmers- More Wheat Per Acre. Again An average production of 124 bushels of wheat per acre is not a record with which we can he satis fied when compared with 19 bushels for the United States, 29 bushels for Nevada, 26.5 for Washington and 25 for Maine. I know of an average Virginia farm on which a yield of 47 bushels per acre was made last year under normal conditions and treat ment and wherever that Is possible by the use-of Intelligence certainly we should not be satisfied with anything leas than an average of 20 bushels throughout the State. On the basis of last years acreage end the average farm price for ten years, a twenty bushel crop throughout the State would add nearly six million dollara to the value of the wheat crop of Vir ginia. More than half a million dollars would be added to the annual value of the oat crop by Increasing the aver age yield from 19.5 to 26 bushels per acre and the annual value of the po tato crop would he increased by more than 8700,000 by raising the average production per acre from 81 to 90 bushels. Are these figures to make any Vir ginian comfortably content with ex isting conditions? Manufacturing In Virginia- Turning now to our record of manufactures. In common with oth er leading Southern States Virginia has demonstrated her ability to com pete with the North In mannfao- tuririy. The last census of manufac tures shows that, as measured by the percentage of Increase in the value of products, the South, aa a whole, had gona forward in the five years from 1904 to 1909 faster than any other sec tion except some of the far Western States where the volume of business done was so small that a relatively slight growth In the value of products showed a large percentage of la- crease. The census of manufactures of 1909 showed that the total value of the products of Virginia factories In that year was 9219,794,000, an In crease in the five years of 47.7 per cent, as compared with an Increase for the United States ef 89.7 per cent Kentucky, with 8223,754,000, was the only State south of the Ohio and Poto mac Rivers that surpassed Virginia in the value of Its manufactured pro ducts. North Carolina, with 52 per cent, was the only Southern State with a higher rate of Increase. Yet, encouraging as these comparative fig ures may be, If we look Into details we can find a basis for that dissatis faction with things as they are which should spur us forward to larger ac complishments. Opportunities Are Abundant. The geographical location of Vir ginia is most favorable for a large de velopment of manufacturing. Among the factors that are potent in deter mining the location of industries are the sources of supply of raw mate rials, an available supply of compe tent labor, markets for finished pro ducts, and transportation facilities for concentrating raw materials and dis tributing finished products- Within the State of Virginia and In the states to the Southward are sources of sup ply of raw materials for a wide diver sity of manufacturing. To the north ward, across the Potomac -River, are the markets of the most densely popu lated region In the United States and outside of the Virginia Capes are the markets of the world- The railway lines of the State are admirably locat ed for the concentration of raw mate rials and for the distribution of manu factured commodities to all parts of the United States and we have direct water transportation not only to all tho oceans of the world, but also by way of the Atlantic Ocean and Chesa peake Bay to the seacoast elttes of the United States. For certain kinds of manufacturing we have a supply of white labor which has not yet been fully availed of. These are reasons why Virginia should play even a larg er part than she does In the manufac turing Industries of the South. Cotton Mills In Virginia. Chief among these Industries is one which every Southern man, and not least every Virginian, should regard with a thrill of pridefor the fact that supremacy in cotton manufactur ing In the United States has passed from the North to theSouth. For sev eral years Southern mills have con sumed more cotton than those In all the other States. In the eleven months ended June 30, 1915, Southern mills consumed 421,714 more bales than were used In all the other States and consumption in Southern mills increased 31,000 bales while In all oth er States It decreased 108,432 bales, With the Northern limit of the cot ton belt within her borders, Virginia lies In the direct line from the cotton fields to the domestic and foreign mar kets for cotton goods. Virginia has flourishing cotton manufacturing in dustry, which, in 1909, turned out pro ducts to the value of 37,933,000, an in crease in five years of 67 per cent. document.text: A large number of people who glory in the sight and sound of trains will converge on Roanoke over Labor Day week-end for three intensive days of riding their hob by- It will be the annual convention of the National Railway Historical Society, Inc., and s-ome 400 mem bers from thirty-odd chapters all over the country will attend. There will be no business sessions, resolu tions or long-winded speeches for these railfans. They will just look, ride and take pictures. Plans for Saturday, August 31 are for tours of Norfolk and West erns shops and Shaffers Crossing engine facilities, the Virginian Rail ways yard and engine house and optional trips on an NW branch or to the nearby summit of the Blue Ridge where heavy main line steam trains surmount the grade. The only formal gathering will be a Saturday night banquet in the Hotel Roanake ballroom.
